THE War Cabinet were informed that the DefenceCommittee (Operations) had had under consideration that morning the terms on which we should be prepared to agree to the cessation of hostilities in Syria. [See telegram No. 2826'Trom Washington.]Drafts had been prepared of (a) A telegram to Washington,(6) A telegram^to the Commanders-in-Chief in the middle east, commenting on the terms which they had proposed.The War Cabinet- .(1) Approved the immediate despatch of these telegrams,subject to amendment as indicated in discussion.(2) Invited the Foreign Secretary to consider whether it wouldbe desirable that a separate declaration should be issued,reaffirming the statement which we had made at the timewhen our forces had entered Syria, to the effect thatour object was to keep the Axis Powers out of thatcountry, and to secure the liberation of its inhabitantsfrom German and Italian domination.Military 2. The War Cabinet were given the latest information in operations regard to the operations in the Western Desert. In the early stages(continued). this operation had developed favourably. The War Cabinet were informed of certain action whichwas being taken-or was contemplated by the United StatesGovernment. A record is contained in the Secretary's standard file of War Cabinet Conclusions.Shipping. 4. The Prime Minister said that he had further considered thisPublication of matter since the last meeting. While he still attached importance to shipping Losses, getting free of the obligation to publish these figures at regular(Previous monthly intervals, he thought that there was much to be said for reference: publishing the figures for May and for June which would probablyW.M. (41) 60th be a better month and ceasing publication thereafter. It would conclusions, be particularly difficult to deny publication of the May losses justMinute 4.) before the Debate on shipping matters. Accordingly, he had notsent the proposed personal telegram to Mr. Hopkins. No indicationshould be given to the Press at this stage of any intention to discontinue publication. But he proposed, in the Debate on shipping matters in the House of Commons, to inform the house in secret session of the argument put forward by the First Lordagainst monthly publication of these losses, namely, that it gave theenemy accurate information, which they could not otherwise obtain,as to the effect of changes in their submarine strategy.The First Lord of the Admiralty said that he was in generalagreement with this view. The shipping losses for June, as so farreported, were 135,000 tons, and he hoped that they would be lower than those for May; but there was reason to believe that a very large number of enemy submarines were now operating. he proposed that the statement to the Press on the May losses shouldbe on the normal lines. The losses for May would be given(analysed between British, Allied and Neutral) together with the adjustments for the four previous months. This announcement would! be made at about 4 p.m. on the following day.The War Cabinet-Authorised the First Lord of the Admiralty to make anannouncement as to shipping losses on the following dayon the lines indicated by him at ".X."Shipping. 5. These were : (i) Action regarding French Indo-China.(ii) Action regarding Free French ships and ships manned by Free French crews.The War Cabinet Authorised the First Lord of the Admiralty to despatchthe signals attached to W.P. (41) 132.U.S.S.R.(previous reference:W.M. (41) 60thConclusions,Minute 3.)7. The War Cabinet were informed that there was no changein the position between Russia and! Germany. The question was raised what line should be taken in regard to publicity if war broke out between Germany and Russia.The Prime Minister said that Germany should be represented as an insatiable tyrant, that had attacked Russia in order to obtainmaterial for carrying on the war.The War Cabinet took note of the above statements.Great George Street, S. "Conty, Director of Political Affairs, has justrequested, on instructions from French High Commissioner, that united States Consul-General enquire of British authorities,as if it were on his own initiative, terms which the french in Syria could expect to obtain if they were to decide thetime had come to invite United States Consul-General to use his good offices to bring about cessation of hostilities,Conty mentioned report that the Free French had condemnedDentz and other French officials to death and indicated that such action was hardly calculated to bring about suitableatmosphere for negotiations. Syrian authorities were therefore very anxious to know in some detail what HisMajestyfs Government and de Gaullists proposed to do asregards1^ the French army of the Levant2) French Civil Servants in Syria and the Lebanon.3)- all other French nationals and their families inthose [? grp. omitted: territories]Although Conty did not say so, he implied that hewas speaking on behalf of the French High Commissioner; he also..implied, that the question was very urgent and that itshould be dealt with with great discretion since theFrench authorities did not wish to give the impression thatthey were suing for peace.United States Consul-General replied that while he couldnot on his own initiative forward these enquiries direct tothe British authorities in the Near East, he would be glad to telegraph to Washington with request that the matter bebrought to the attention of the British Government. Contyagreed to this procedure, provided that United States Consul-General could be authorized to exercise his good offices withoutfurther instructions in the event of the French deciding to ask him to do so. "United States United States Consul-General commented that he thought itsignificant that Conty never once, referred to Vichy Governmentand that he apparently did not have in mind an armisticeor negotiations of a. purely military character. On. thecontrary, Conty-said that the French authorities were anxiousto know what political arrangements' could be made with theBritish and Free French authorities.-- - - * - - -".....-----United States Consul-General-1 s impression is that French are tired and" that they have not received reinforcements' from france. He felt that they would probably be-prepared., toaccept terms that would safeguard all British, military, navaland air requirements provided that they.were otherwise sufficientlygenerous to enable the French to yield with honour." [Ends],3. State Department at the same time conveyed message fromMr. Welles.a') That in view of the speed with which things mightmove United States Government hoped that His Majesty's government might be able to. give a reply by tomorroyf morning June" 19th and b) that his feeling was that the occasion.was one on whicha handsome and "chevaleresque" response from His Majesty'sGovernment might bring great profits.4. The State Department official felt certain thatif His Majesty's Government wished the United States Consul-General Beirut to negotiate, the United States Governmentwould be ready to give him the free hand apparently desired by the French High Commissioner Syria,[Being repeated to Cairo No: 2134 for Commanders in Chief], COPY191Telegram to Viscount Halifax, Washington^ Repeated to Cairofor Commanders-in-Chief.MOST IMMEDIATE.Your telegram No. 2826 (of 18th June: Syria).You may assure State Department that His Majesty'sGovernment would he very ready to consider satisfactory arrangement whereby our strategic requirements in Syria are fully safeguarded. Far from desiring to impose any dis-honourable terms on General Dentz, H.M.G. are fully preparedto accord full honours of war to him and other civil andmilitary officers, who have only done what they conceive to be their duty by their Government.2. There is therefore no question of General Dentz or anyother civil or military official being condemned to death or toany other penalty.3. Following is outline of terms which we would beprepared to accept.(l) Negotiations for cessation of hostilities to becarried out "between General Wilson representing Commanders-in-Chief and Vichy authorities in Syria.(2) Hostilities to cease at once and Vichy forces to concentrate in selected areas. All compliments of war willhe accorded.(3) (a) Surrender of all warships and of all navalestablishments intact.Note: Should this be unacceptahle the following alternative has been authorised. "Warships to he handed overintact for internment and subsequently to be reduced to care and maintenance basis at Beirut with power to move as ordered by Commander-in-Chief, Mediterranean,if safety considerationsdemand it." In either alternative,return of ships after war to a friendly France or compensation is guaranteed.(b) All other ships including British and harbours and services to be handed over intact.(4) All aircraft whether Vichy or Axis and war material to be handed over undamaged.(5) All service personnel to be given opportunity to joinFree French. Those who do not wish to do so will be repatriated as and when possible.(6) High Commissioner his staff and all French officials and nationals other than those who are prepared to remain willbe repatriated as and when possible.(7) All ports aerodromes communications fuel stocks and installations to be handed over intact for our use.(8) Exact position of minefields will be disclosed. (9) Administrative and public utility services to be maintained,operated if or the time "being under allied military direction.(10) Gable and wireless services to cease operations andto be handed over intact.
